text.content: No matter how long your loved one has lived with PTSD, there are treatments that can help.

Talking to a professional is one of the best things your loved one can do to help with PTSD.  There are several evidence-based treatments that have been shown to be effective in reducing PTSD symptoms.
Your support can go a long way in helping your loved one. Studies have shown that support from loved ones improves both treatment and recovery from PTSD.

Having a loved one with PTSD can be incredibly stressful. It's important that you prioritize yourself and your needs, at least some of the time. You can't help your loved one if you don’t take care of yourself too.

PTSD affects everyone differently, but it's extremely common for loved ones to experience significant stress. Don't be afraid to seek out help and support to help you deal with any stress you’re experiencing.
Over 600,000 Veterans who used VA services as recently as 2016 were diagnosed with PTSD.
5 out of every 100 active duty Service Members were estimated to have PTSD after deployment.
For those in infantry units that experienced combat, 13 out of every 100 Service Members had PTSD.
Psychotherapy and/or medication are the most effective treatments for PTSD.  Trauma-focused psychotherapy is considered more effective than medications.

Treatments for PTSD have been shown to improve symptoms, personal and professional relationships, and quality of life.  Talked to your loved one’s providers about which PTSD treatment is right for them.

These therapies use different techniques to help your loved one  process their traumatic experience. Some involve visualizing, talking, or thinking about the traumatic memory, while others focus on changing unhelpful beliefs.

There are several trauma-focused psychotherapies that have been shown to help improve PTSD: Prolonged Exposure (PE), Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT), Eye-Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR), Brief Eclectic Psychotherapy, Narrative Exposure Therapy, and Written Narrative Exposure.

Medications that can be helpful for PTSD are also used for depression and anxiety: sertraline (Zoloft), paroxetine (Paxil), fluoxetine (Prozac), and venlafaxine (Effexor).  Talk to your doctor about whether a prescription could be helpful for your loved one.
